Agree with ABE

HCX, Log Insight, Site Recovery are all options after deployment

Selected Answer: ABE
Easy one - ABE

Selected Answer: ABE
A, B and E are deployed by default. While the others are also behind the T1 mgmt GW they are not default components.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vmc-aws-networking-security/GUID-658253DB-F384-4040-94B2-DF2AC3C9D396.html
A,B and E are correct

questions.question_text:
When deploying a VMware Cloud on AWS software-defined data center (SDDC), which three default components are located behind the T1 Management
Gateway? (Choose three.)

choices.A: Choose a connected Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) that is located in the same region as the native AWSservices to be consumed.
choices.C: Choose a subnet from the connected Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) that is located in the same availability zone as the native AWS services to be consumed.
choices.B: Any availability zone within the same AWS region can be selected. After the SDDC deployment, deploy a services gateway and connect it to the target availability zone.
choices.D: Choose a connected Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) that is located in the same availability zone as the native AWS services to be consumed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
+1 for CCC
I agree with C too
I agree, C is correct.

Selected Answer: C
C – Cross AZ traffic incurs charges. If the SDCC is configured in AZ1 and native services are in AZ2 charges $0.01/GB will apply.
https://www.gilles.cloud/2018/06/understanding-vmware-cloud-on-aws.html

questions.question_text:
A customer is deploying a new solution based on VMware Cloud on AWS. The customer is already running several native AWS services and would like the new workloads deployed into VMware Cloud on AWS to consume these services without incurring additional traffic charges. During the initial deployment of the
VMware Cloud on AWS software-defined data center (SDDC), which option must the customer choose to meet the requirement?
Which statement is true regarding how vSphere High Availability (HA) provides rapid recovery from outages in VMware Cloud on AWS?

discussion.content: A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
Looks like A is the answer

Selected Answer: A
A is correct, B is not possible because VM restart in another host when happens outages in SDDC not application.

Selected Answer: A
I'm also going with A
Here is a good article explaining vsan network isolation
https://www.yellow-bricks.com/2017/11/08/vsphere-ha-heartbeat-datastores-isolation-address-vsan/

Selected Answer: A
A is correct!

Correct answer is A
vSphere HA restarts VMs if their host becomes isolated on the vSAN network.
Host network isolation occurs when a host is still running, but it can no longer observe traffic from the vSphere HA agents on the vSAN network: 
• vSphere HA tries to ping the cluster isolation addresses. 
• If pinging fails, the host declares that it is isolated from the network. 
This protection is provided even if the network becomes partitioned.
I am going to go with A for this answer

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
A is correct. HA resets machines when a VM stops sending heartbeats or the VM process fails (vmx) alright, but they restart on the same host.
A is correct; https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vsan-planning.doc/GUID-D68890D8-841A-4BD1-ACA1-DA3D25B6A37A.html
Correct answer should be D
B and D reset vm on same host, C is not allowed.

choices.C: vSphere HA is enabled by default in VMware Cloud on AWS but can be disabled or modified.
choices.D: vSphere HA restarts impacted virtual machines (VMs) on another host when a VM stops sending heartbeats or the VM process fails (vmx).
choices.A: Sphere HA restarts virtual machines if their host becomes isolated on the VMware vSAN network.
choices.B: vSphere HA restarts impacted virtual machines on another host when an application fails.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the only right answer

Selected Answer: C
+1 for CCC
I agree with C

Selected Answer: C
I agree, C is correct.
Also see, https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Disaster-Recovery/services/rn/vmware-cloud-disaster-recovery-release-notes/index.html?msclkid=44fdf937cf8b11ec913933080c222499

C – Minimum RPO for VCDR is 30 minutes, so using it for all three sites wouldn’t maintain the recovery time for the main data center as required.
https://blogs.vmware.com/virtualblocks/2021/09/02/whats-new-30-minute-rpo/

Selected Answer: C
It should be C - Site Recovery fulfills RPO&RTO for main site and VCDR improves these parameters for branches.

choices.A: Create a software-defined data center (SDDC) in VMware Cloud on AWS. Create a shared content librand let the branch offices subscribe to it. Export the virtual machines in the branch offices to OVF files on the shared content library on a weekly basis.
choices.C: Create a software-defined data center (SDDC) in VMware Cloud on AWS. Activate VMware Site Recovery. Replace the co-located disaster recovery (DR) site for the main data center with VMware Site Recovery. For the branch offices, implement VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery (VCDR).
choices.B: Create a software-defined data center (SDDC) in VMware Cloud on AWS. Migrate the disaster recovery solution from the co-located data center to the VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC. Create regular copies of the virtual machines at the branch offices and use AWS Snowball to directly ship the copies to an AWS data center and store them on AWS S3 buckets.
choices.D: Create a software-defined data center (SDDC) in VMware Cloud on AWS. Replace the co-located site for the main data center and the backup tape shipping for the branch offices with VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery (VCDR).

questions.question_text: A company is operating a main data center and two smaller data centers in branch offices. The main data center is being replicated to a disaster recovery site at a co-located data center with a recovery point objective (RPO) of five minutes and a recovery time objective (RTO) of two hours. The branch data centers are shipping backup tapes to the main data center on a weekly basis. What would be a cost-efficient VMware solution that would improve RTO and RPO for the branch office data centers while maintaining the recovery time for the main data center?

A customer plans to use VMware Cloud on AWS to support their public cloud adoption initiatives. Their use case for VMware Cloud on AWS is predominately data center extension to support seasonal and business specific demands. There will also be a number of workloads running in VMware Cloud on AWS on a long-term, permanent basis. Based on a recent sizing assessment, it is determined that utilization of VMware Cloud on AWS will fluctuate between two and five hosts throughout the year based on seasonal and market conditions. Which possible subscription option would result in the greatest benefit to this customer and why?

choices.A: Create a subscription for five hosts for three years. This option provides the greatest cost savings to the customer and eliminates the amount of time needed to provision and configure VMware ESXi hosts as consumption fluctuates.
choices.B: Create a subscription for two hosts for one year and consume the remaining hosts, as needed, on-demand. This option allows the customer to lock in a term rate for required hosts and leverage on-demand rates for additional hosts as needed.
choices.D: Create a subscription for three hosts for three years and consume the remaining hosts, as needed, on-demand. This option allows the customer to lock in a term rate for required hosts and leverage on-demand rates for additional hosts as needed.
choices.C: Consume VMware Cloud on AWS on-demand based on seasonal and business requirements. This option provides the cost benefits of cloud through an on- demand consumption model.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think you cannot scale down from 5 hosts to 2 hosts, so subscription for 3 hosts makes sense.

Selected Answer: D
D = greatest benefit for sure

comments.content:
https://www.vmware.com/products/vmc-on-aws.html#pricing
3 hosts on a 3-yeas subscription @ 109 336$ = 328 008$ for 3 year
2 hosts on a 1-year subscription @ 51 987$ = 311 922$ for 3 year
By adding the hosts who will be paid on demand, the option of 3 hosts will be advantageous.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
As per me D is correct as 3 host for three year subscription would be cheaper than 2 hosts for a one year subscription and as it is mentioned that the workloads would be running on AWS for a long term, permanent basis, so it makes more sense to invest in a bigger subscription than to opt for on demand hosts which are obviously costlier than subscription based hosts.
I believe it's B as well.
D as the large cost savings via discounts will outweigh it being sat under utilised at points

I'd say B it's a better option, no point in having 3 Hosts all the time if the minimum they required is 2, of course, an additional Host would help in case of failure, but B is still more cost-effective
